item.title: The US Has the Highest Corporate Tax Rate in the Developed World, The US Has Highest Tax Rate in the World
item.description:
In fact, when it comes to business tax, we are now dead last among developed nations. We pay the highest tax of any nation in the world. Our rate is the least competitive rate there is.

— Donald Trump, remarks to National Association of Manufacturers

Claims:

The US Has the Highest Corporate Tax Rate in the Developed World
The Truth:
The US does have a high statutory rate (up to 35%), but significant deductions and exemptions mean companies actually end up paying a much lower rate; the effective tax rate is about average. Furthermore, while the statutory rate is relatively high, it is not the highest in the developed world; that distinction goes to the United Arab Emirates with rates up to 55%.
The US Has Highest Tax Rate in the World
The Truth:
It doesn’t.

item.title: The Estate Tax Has a Significant Effect on Small Businesses
item.description:
To protect millions of small businesses and the American farmer, we are finally ending the crushing, the horrible, the unfair estate tax, or as it is often referred to, the death tax.

— Donald Trump, speech on tax reform

Claims:

The Estate Tax Has a Significant Effect on Small Businesses
The Truth:
Very, very few small businesses are effected by the estate tax.

Fact Checks:

PolitiFact
That’s a ridiculously high estimate. Only 5,460 estates even pay the tax each year, according to a credible estimate, and of those, about 80 represented small businesses or farms.
The Washington Post

The president’s suggestion that “millions” of small businesses and farms are affected by the estate tax is absurd. According to the nonpartisan Tax Policy Center, only about 5,500 estates in 2017 – out of nearly 3 million estates – would have to pay any taxes. About half of estates subject to the tax would pay an average tax of about 9 percent. That’s because for a married couple, about $11 million is exempt from taxation.

Only 80 – that’s right, 80 – taxable estates would be farms and small businesses.

item.title: The Estate Tax Strongly Affects Farmers
item.description:
The farmers, in particular, are affected. They have wonderful farms, but they can’t pay the tax, so they have to sell the farm.

— Donald Trump, speech on tax reform

Claims:

The Estate Tax Strongly Affects Farmers
The Truth:
Very few farms are large enough to qualify for the estate tax.

Fact Checks:

FactCheck.org

A study published last year and updated in March by the Economic Research Service of the U.S. Department of Agriculture estimated that 38,328 farms would become part of estates in 2016, of which only 0.42 percent — 161 estates — would owe any estate tax at all.

Separate research by the nonpartisan Tax Policy Center puts the number even lower. TPC estimates that only 50 farms and closely held businesses will pay any estate tax in 2017.

Associated Press
That assertion appears to be at odds with statistics. Only 1.7 percent of family-farm estates were required to file an estate-tax return in 2016 and only 0.4 percent ended up owing the tax, according to an analysis by the Agriculture Department. Overall, the very rich are affected in particular.

item.title: Trump Wouldn't Benefit From GOP Tax Plan
item.description:
I’m doing the right thing, and it’s not good for me. Believe me.

— Donald Trump, speech on tax reform

Claims:

Trump Wouldn't Benefit From GOP Tax Plan
The Truth:
Since he hasn’t released his taxes it’s difficult to analyze this, but his leaked 2005 returns show he would definitely benefit from abolishing the AMT, and his heirs would benefit from abolishing the estate tax.

Fact Checks:

The Washington Post

Of course, he has not released his tax returns, so it is difficult to know for sure. But he is certainly subject to the AMT – and the one recent tax return that has been leaked, from 2005, shows that the AMT increased his tax bill from about $5.3 million to $36.5 million. So at least in that tax year, he potentially could have saved $31 million.

Eliminating the estate tax, meanwhile, is likely to benefit his heirs.

Time
Of course, Trump was the first major-party presidential candidate since 1976 not to release his tax returns, so it’s hard to say exactly how he’ll be affected. But based on tax returns which have become public and what we know of his finances, there are at least three key ways he could benefit.

item.title: Trump Wouldn't Benefit From GOP Tax Plan
item.description:
No, I don’t benefit. I don’t benefit.

— Donald Trump, press gaggle

Claims:

Trump Wouldn't Benefit From GOP Tax Plan
The Truth:
Since he hasn’t released his taxes it’s difficult to analyze this, but his leaked 2005 returns show he would definitely benefit from abolishing the AMT, and his heirs would benefit from abolishing the estate tax.

Fact Checks:

PolitiFact
Trump’s refusal to release his tax returns makes it impossible to quantify exactly how much he would personally benefit from his policy proposals. But what is known about Trump’s past patterns of taxation and his income and wealth holdings strongly suggest that at least three proposed changes – to the alternative minimum tax, to the tax on “passthrough” income, and to the estate tax – would benefit Trump or his family either immediately or down the road.
